{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3371489,"name":"Gal","username":"GalDotan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galdotan/{size}/201749_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-23T21:29:37.842Z","cooked":"

This off-season we are looking into upping our software. One of the main issues we had during our season is making the software side of the robot repitable. We are already working on a better solution for localisation and a new vision approach/system.

But how do your team makes your software more reliable? Anything from controlling motors, auto align, flywheels control, and complex systems (like a double joint) control will be helpful.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-04-23T21:29:37.842Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":331,"readers_count":330,"score":196.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464245,"topic_slug":"how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable","display_username":"Gal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60986,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5951 Software and electrical lead"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable/464245/1","custom_user_title":"5951 Software and electrical lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3373573,"name":"Avi","username":"Avi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avi/{size}/214903_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-25T18:07:41.589Z","cooked":"

I’m not totally sure what you mean by reliable. In terms of consistency we just do as much testing as we can, plus graphing the outputs we care about like speed for flywheels. Then if the graphs aren’t looking like what we want them to we’ll keep tuning the PID until they look like what we want.

We use PID for all of these:

GalDotan:

controlling motors, auto align, flywheels control

except for when the exact speed of a motor doesn’t matter in which case we’ll just give it a set voltage or percent output.

From looking at your team’s code available on GitHub, I notice two areas that could greatly improve your repeatability and reliability; filters and motion profiling. I’ve linked WPILib Documentation on both that should give you a good bit of information on how to incorporate these into your code base!

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T04:08:47.222Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":55.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464245,"topic_slug":"how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable","display_username":"Carlos Salazar","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/filters/index.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Filters — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":17},{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/controllers/index.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Controllers — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programming & Electrical Captain"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable/464245/3","custom_user_title":"Programming & Electrical Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375794,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T04:29:00.253Z","cooked":"

The conference talk on WPIlib unexplored areas talks about using logs, which I think give you better insight into how the robot is performing. We implemented monologue and used the generated log files in AdvantageScope to see how the robot performed. I think reviewing some things like that and drive station logs can help you identify possible issues earlier and avoid some problems. We found a code bug after reviewing our chassis speed during autos that when fixed made our auto paths much more reliable. By logging PID setpoints and sensor values you can see how well your tuning is working. By checking your odometry you can see if your camera performing as expected. Even seeing things like how our arm was exceeding current limits during climbs until we increased it were present in logs to see. So I’d look into having that capability.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T04:29:00.253Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":162,"readers_count":161,"score":52.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464245,"topic_slug":"how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable/464245/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375795,"name":"Richard Wallace","username":"Richard_Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T04:52:20.011Z","cooked":"

Asking a question is always the best way to start learning, so good on you for getting off on the right foot.

Reliable, repeatable, reputable. Maybe that’s what repitable means?

Anyway, well structured, documented, reviewable and unit-testable code is the foundation of software that performs functions that are critical to safety or to any important function (and why bother if it’s not important?)

Engineers who have developed code for aerospace components and systems, medical devices, industrial equipment, automotive applications, consumer appliances, and other critical functions will be familiar with how it gets developed, documented, validated, and certified. Some of that relies on a development process and toolset, but the more important part is the mindset — what can go wrong? How can the code prevent that?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-04-28T04:52:20.011Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":125,"readers_count":124,"score":40.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464245,"topic_slug":"how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable","display_username":"Richard Wallace","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1549,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I live for the details."},"post_url":"/t/how-to-make-your-software-more-repitable/464245/5","custom_user_title":"I live for the details.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3375802,"name":"coderkevin","username":"coderkevin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/coderkevin/{size}/98679_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-28T05:12:41.834Z","cooked":"
GalDotan:

controlling motors, auto align, flywheels control, and complex systems (like a double joint) control will be helpful.

These are all examples of things that should be tuned, like PIDs and motion control. Couple things to keep in mind when tuning your robot:

  1. Know and conceptualize what’s going on when you tune a thing. Make sure you know what the inputs should be doing.

  2. Tune in real-time. Having to rebuild/redeploy when adjusting a value is a drag. Put it on shuffleboard/elastic/whatever and tune it there. Then, when you have values you like, you can hard code them in constants.

  3. Don’t settle. Robot movements should be snappy and accurate. Auto paths should be accurate to 1-3 inches if possible. Mechanisms should move in 1 second or less, if possible, and they should sit accurately. For some things one small bounce is acceptable, but there should be no oscillating but it should be fast.

We have added an option to our library where you can publish data to the NT. Then you can view in in real and log it to wpilog. Haven’t got deep into logging but we already see the ease of use and the advantage it added. Thank you for your help!
